description: From Middle English frensy, frenesie, from Old French frenesie, from Latin phrenesis, from Ancient Greek *φρένησις (*phrénēsis), a later equivalent of φρενῖτις (phrenîtis, “inflammation of the brain”): see frantic and frenetic.

adjectives.description: frenzy (comparative more frenzy, superlative most frenzy)

examples: They thought that some frenzy distemper had got into his head.

entries.meaning: A state of wild activity or panic.
examples: She went into a cleaning frenzy to prepare for the unexpected guests.

entries.meaning: A violent agitation of the mind approaching madness; rage.

verbs.description: frenzy (third-person singular simple present frenzies, present participle frenzying, simple past and past participle frenzied)

examples: Both goaded on to strife by frenzying hate.

entries.meaning: (rare) To exhibit a frenzy, such as a feeding frenzy.
examples: The fresh smell of salt air, the sound of the crashing swell, the soothing immersion in the water, the sight of dolphins playing and fish frenzying beneath my board.
